alignment score: A 1–5 scale rating of how well the model's response matched the user's intent, assigned by an LLM annotator for each task.
compaction: Claude Code's process of summarizing earlier messages to free context window space when the conversation grows too long.
subagent: A separate Claude instance spawned by the main agent to handle a specific subtask autonomously.
planning mode: A preliminary phase where the agent outlines its approach before implementation, either self-initiated or user-requested.
tool calls: Individual function invocations by Claude Code: Read, Edit, Write, Grep, Glob, Bash, etc.
prompt caching: An API feature that stores frequently-used conversation context to reduce redundant token processing across round-trips.
context window: The maximum amount of text (in tokens) that Claude can process in a single conversation.
iterative refinement: Sequential edits to the same code region without error signals or user dissatisfaction—normal incremental development.
self-correction: When the agent rewrites its own code within the same task without any error or user prompt.
error recovery: When the agent rewrites code after a tool error (test failure, syntax error, compilation failure) occurred.
user-directed correction: When the agent rewrites code in a later task after the user expressed dissatisfaction with the original.
edit overlap: When a later edit's old_string contains text from an earlier edit's new_string on the same file, indicating rework.
rewrite rate: The fraction of all edits that overlap with a previous edit on the same file—a proxy for how much code gets reworked.
task complexity: LLM-assigned difficulty: trivial (one-line), simple (small feature), moderate (multi-file), complex (architectural), major (large-scale).
one-shot rate: Percentage of tasks completed in a single agent turn without back-and-forth interaction.
front-loading: Allocating research tool calls (Read, Grep, Glob) disproportionately toward the beginning of a task.
bonferroni correction: A statistical adjustment that lowers the significance threshold when performing multiple tests to reduce false positives. Here: p<0.00048 (0.05/105).
mann-whitney u: A nonparametric test comparing continuous metrics between two groups without assuming normal distributions.
effect size: A standardized measure of difference magnitude independent of sample size. Cohen’s d: 0.2 small, 0.5 medium, 0.8 large.
satisfaction rate: Percentage of tasks where the user expressed explicit satisfaction with the agent's work.
completion rate: Percentage of tasks classified as fully completed rather than partial, interrupted, or failed.
user correction rate: Percentage of edits that the agent later rewrote after user dissatisfaction signals.
explore agent: A read-only subagent type for research tasks, with Read/Grep/Glob tools but no file modification.
general-purpose: A full-capability subagent type with access to all tools including Edit, Write, and Bash.
control group: Non-compacting sessions used as a baseline, split at the median compaction position to isolate position effects from compaction effects.
output tokens: Tokens generated by the model in its response, including visible text, thinking, and tool call arguments.
input tokens: Tokens sent to the model per API request, including conversation history, system prompt, and tool results.
API round-trips: Individual request-response cycles between the Claude Code client and the Claude API. Fewer round-trips mean less repeated context transmission.
thinking: An internal reasoning step where the model generates chain-of-thought text not shown to the user. Measured in characters; converted to estimated tokens at ~3 chars/token.
pp: Percentage points—the arithmetic difference between two percentages, as opposed to a relative percentage change.
Cohen\u2019s d: Effect size for comparing two group means, in units of pooled standard deviation. 0.2 = small, 0.5 = medium, 0.8 = large.
Cram\u00e9r\u2019s V: Effect size for categorical associations in chi-square tests, ranging from 0 (none) to 1 (perfect).
Cohen\u2019s h: Effect size for comparing two proportions. 0.2 = small, 0.5 = medium, 0.8 = large.
chi-square: A statistical test for comparing categorical distributions between two groups to determine if differences are significant.
proportion tests: Statistical tests comparing rates or percentages between two groups, such as completion rate differences.
edit timeline analysis: Reconstructing the chronological sequence of all Edit/Write tool calls per session to detect when later edits modify regions written by earlier ones.
old_string: In the Edit tool, the exact text to find and replace. When a later edit’s old_string overlaps an earlier edit’s new_string, it indicates rework.
new_string: In the Edit tool, the replacement text. Overlap between this and a later edit’s old_string signals the earlier output was revised.
chain depth: The number of successive overlapping edits to the same code region—a depth of 3 means the code was rewritten three times.
duration tercile: Tasks divided into three equal-sized groups (short/medium/long) by duration, used to control for time-on-task.
dissatisfaction signals: Keywords in the user’s next message (“wrong”, “revert”, “fix that”) indicating rejection of the agent’s output.
background tasks: Subagent processes running concurrently with the main agent, allowing parallel execution.
foreground tasks: Subagent processes that block the main conversation until they complete.
false positive rate: The proportion of flagged cases incorrectly identified—here, dissatisfaction signals that were actually normal task-coordination language.
LLM annotator: A language model (Claude Haiku or Sonnet) used to automatically classify tasks for complexity, sentiment, and other attributes.
compact_boundary: A system message marking where compaction occurred, containing trigger type and pre-compaction token count.
pre-compaction tokens: The total token count at the moment compaction triggers, indicating how full the context window was.
content ownership maps: Per-file records tracking which edit introduced each line, enabling detection of when later edits overwrite earlier ones.
complexity confound: A bias where one model’s higher proportion of complex tasks inflates resource metrics and may suppress outcome scores.
